question_details.query: What is the most cost-effective method for reducing human-primate conflict in agricultural areas?

summary_details.relevant_summary: There is no evidence for the effects of removing human food waste (1561), installing mechanical barriers (1436), using predator scents (1448), using tracking devices for early warning (1443), changing to less palatable crops (1439), or using unpalatable buffer crops (1438) on primate populations or their conflict with humans.
summary_statements: There is no evidence for the effects of removing human food waste on primate populations or on primate conflict with humans.
There is no evidence for the effects of installing mechanical barriers on primate populations or on primate conflict with humans.
There is no evidence for the effects of using predator scents on primate populations or on primate conflict with humans.
There is no evidence for the effects of using tracking devices for early warning on primate populations or on primate conflict with humans.
There is no evidence for the effects of changing to less palatable crops on primate populations or on primate conflict with humans.
There is no evidence for the effects of using unpalatable buffer crops on primate populations or on primate conflict with humans.

question_details.query: How does the success rate of primate reintroduction programs vary between different continents?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
In Africa, a reintroduced chimpanzee population in Tanzania increased in size (1589). In Guinea and the Republic of Congo, most reintroduced chimpanzees survived for at least one to five years (1591). In Senegal, an infant chimpanzee was reunited with its mother (1589). In Uganda, a reintroduced chimpanzee repeatedly returned to human settlements (1591). In Madagascar and South Africa, a minority of primates survived for at least fifteen weeks to seven years (1591). In both Gabon and South Africa, a majority of primates survived for at least two months to one year (1591). The diet of reintroduced lemurs in Madagascar was found to overlap with that of wild lemurs (1596, 1591).

In Asia, primate populations in Thailand declined after reintroduction (1591, 1589). In Indonesia, Malaysia, and Vietnam, a minority of primates survived for between two months and one year (1589), while another study in Vietnam found that half of the introduced primates survived after two months (1589). In Indonesia, reintroduced gibbons and other primates showed similar behavior and diets to wild populations (1589, 1591). A study in Malaysia found that a reintroduced orangutan population declined, though 98% of the orangutans survived the release (1589).

In South America, a minority of primates in Brazil and French Guiana survived for at least fifteen weeks to seven years (1591). A reintroduced primate population in Brazil declined (1589), but in other instances, an abandoned infant muriqui was reunited with its mother (1589), and a reintroduced muriqui rejoined a wild group (1591). In Brazil, a majority of primates survived for at least two months to one year (1591), and in another case, two out of three reintroduced black lion tamarins survived for over four months (1596). In French Guiana, a majority of primates survived for at least two months to one year (1591).

In Central America, a study in Belize found that the primate population increased five years after reintroduction (1591).
summary_statements: A reintroduced chimpanzee population in Tanzania increased in size.
In Guinea and the Republic of Congo, most reintroduced chimpanzees survived for at least one to five years.
In Senegal, an infant chimpanzee was reunited with the chimpanzee's mother.
In Uganda, a reintroduced chimpanzee repeatedly returned to human settlements.
In Madagascar and South Africa, a minority of primates survived for at least fifteen weeks to seven years.
In both Gabon and South Africa, a majority of primates survived for at least two months to one year.
The diet of reintroduced lemurs in Madagascar was found to overlap with the diet of wild lemurs.
Primate populations in Thailand declined after reintroduction.
In Indonesia, Malaysia, and Vietnam, a minority of primates survived for between two months and one year.
A study in Vietnam found that half of the introduced primates survived after two months.
In Indonesia, reintroduced gibbons and other primates showed similar behavior and diets to wild populations.
A study in Malaysia found that a reintroduced orangutan population declined.
A Malaysian study found that 98% of the orangutans survived the release.
In Brazil and French Guiana, a minority of primates survived for at least fifteen weeks to seven years.
A reintroduced primate population in Brazil declined.
In Brazil, an abandoned infant muriqui was reunited with the muriqui's mother.
A reintroduced muriqui in Brazil rejoined a wild group.
In Brazil, a majority of primates survived for at least two months to one year.
In one case in Brazil, two out of three reintroduced black lion tamarins survived for over four months.
In French Guiana, a majority of primates survived for at least two months to one year.
A study in Belize found that the primate population increased five years after reintroduction.

question_details.query: What is the impact of plastic pollution in waterways on primate populations that live near rivers?

summary_details.relevant_summary: We found no studies that evaluated the effects of plastic pollution in waterways on primate populations.
summary_statements: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of plastic pollution in waterways on primate populations.
